title: Phillipsite
text:
Phillipsite is a mineral series of the <a href="zeolite">zeolite</a> group; a hydrated <a href="potassium">potassium</a>, <a href="calcium">calcium</a> and <a href="aluminium">aluminium</a> silicate, approximating to . The members of the series are phillipsite-K, phillipsite-Na and phillipsite-Ca. The crystals are <a href="monoclinic">monoclinic</a>, but only complex cruciform <a href="Crystal%20twinning">twins</a> are known, these being exactly like twins of <a href="harmotome">harmotome</a> which also forms a series with phillipsite-Ca. Crystals of phillipsite are, however, usually smaller and more transparent and glassy than those of harmotome. Spherical groups with a radially fibrous structure and bristled with crystals on the surface are not uncommon. The <a href="Mohs%20hardness">Mohs hardness</a> is 4.5, and the <a href="specific%20gravity">specific gravity</a> is 2.2. The species was established by <a href="Armand%20L%C3%A9vy%20%28mineralogist%29">Armand Lévy</a> in 1825 and named after <a href="William%20Phillips%20%28geologist%29">William Phillips</a>. French authors use the name Christianite (after <a href="Christian%20VIII">Christian VIII</a> of <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a>), given by A. Des Cloizeaux in 1847.
Phillipsite is a mineral of secondary origin, and occurs with other zeolites in the <a href="Amygdule">amygdaloidal</a> cavities of <a href="mafic">mafic</a> <a href="volcanic%20rock">volcanic rock</a>s: for example in the <a href="basalt">basalt</a> of the <a href="Giants%20Causeway">Giants Causeway</a> in County Antrim, and near <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a> in <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a>; and in Lencitite near <a href="Rome">Rome</a>. Small crystals of recent formation have been observed in the masonry of the hot baths at Plombires and Bourbonne-les-Bains, in <a href="France">France</a>. Minute spherical aggregates embedded in <a href="pelagic%20red%20clay">pelagic red clay</a> were dredged by the <a href="Challenger%20expedition">Challenger</a> from deep sea sedimentary deposits in the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>.
It has been discovered that the volcanic ash that Romans employed in the mix for construction of harbor piers and sea walls contained phillipsite, and that an interaction with sea water actually causes crystalline aluminous <a href="tobermorite">tobermorite</a> structures in the mortar to expand and strengthen, making the material substantially more durable than modern concrete.
